awd_titl_txt: Free Probability and Cohomology in von Neumann Algebra Theory.
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental theme in mathematics is that, in many cases, certain aspects of complicated finite-dimensional structures become simpler as the dimension of such structures goes to infinity.  This very paradoxical behavior underlies the theory of thermodynamics in physics, in which complicated systems of particles admit a simpler global description (involving just a few variables, such as pressure and temperature) when the number of particles becomes large.  A mathematical theory of free probability, initiated by Voiculescu in the 1980s, has shown that von Neumann algebras can be viewed as systems of 'thermodynamic variables' for asymptotic behavior of random matrices. A distinctive feature of the theory is that the variables no longer commute: the order of their multiplication matters.  This results in an extremely rich theory that leads to free probability generalizations of classical objects such as partial differential equations, Brownian motion, and so on. The present project concerns questions of better understanding of asymptotic behavior of random matrices and of the resulting asymptotic limit through construction of invariants, which are both algebraic and analytic in nature. 

The project's aim is to continue the study of cohomological invariants associated to subfactors and more general inclusions of algebras, in particular L^2 invariants and their analogs. The study of some of these invariants turns out to involve many analytical tools supplied by free probability theory, such as free probability analogs of Brownian motion and of the associated Laplace-like operators. The study of these operators - arising in the asymptotic limit of random matrices - is of significant interest in random matrix theory as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Work under this award has advanced our understanding of free probability theory.  This theory describes behavior of certain classes of large matrices, and has deep connections with a number of mathematical fields, including operator algebras, probability theory, and random matrix theory.  Beyond interesting mathematics, these fields have direct connections to important applications, ranging from machine learning to quantum mechanics.

The work focused on further development of a theory of transportation in free probability theory.   Classically, transportation theory studies ways to efficiently transport mass -- one of the first publications in that area is by G. Monge in 1781 concerns the question of efficiently transporting a pile of dirt to fill a hole in the ground.  In free probability theory, ideas from classical transportation theory find new context when they are applied to "quantum" random variables that appear in free probability. 

One of the cornerstones of classical transportation theory is a certain duality principle, which converts the original transportation problem into a certain dual problem. The properties of the dual problem can then be useful to study the original problem, and vice-versa.  One of the interesting findings is that it is actually possible to formulate a free probability version of this dual problem.  The resulting theory is not yet fully developed, but promises to bring more classical techniques to the realm of free probability theory.

The award has resulted in 5 publications by the PI and his collaborators.  Three of PI's students have been supported as research assistants by this award.
